unnormalised: One of the most important identifiers is the PNR, or Passenger Name Record. A PNR is a 10-digit number (e.g., 1234567890) that serves as a reservation record in the airline's or railway's database. It contains information like your name, contact details, seat preference, and journey details. You'll find your PNR printed on your ticket, whether it's an e-ticket or a physical one. Use this PNR to check your reservation status online on the IRCTC or airline website.
normalised: One of the most important identifiers is the P-N-R, or Passenger Name Record. A P-N-R is a ten-digit number, for example, one two three four five six seven eight nine zero, that serves as a reservation record in the airline's or railway's database. It contains information like your name, contact details, seat preference, and journey details. You'll find your P-N-R printed on your ticket, whether it's an e-ticket or a physical one. Use this P-N-R to check your reservation status online on the I-R-C-T-C or airline website.

unnormalised: Airline tickets also feature a booking reference number, often a 6-character alphanumeric code (e.g., ABC12D). This code is airline-specific and may be required for online check-in or managing your booking. Don't confuse this with the PNR, although both identify your reservation. Many low-cost carriers, such as IndiGo and SpiceJet, rely heavily on this booking reference number for all transactions.

unnormalised: For train travel, the IRCTC (Indian Railway Catering and Tourism Corporation) provides additional identifiers. Each ticket includes a transaction ID, a unique number generated for each booking (e.g., 1011223344). This transaction ID is useful for tracking your payment history and raising any issues with your booking. Furthermore, each train has a 5-digit train number (e.g., 12001) used for searching train schedules and tracking its real-time location.
normalised: For train travel, the I-R-C-T-C (Indian Railway Catering and Tourism Corporation) provides additional identifiers. Each ticket includes a transaction I-D, a unique number generated for each booking, for example, one zero one one two two three three four four. This transaction I-D is useful for tracking your payment history and raising any issues with your booking. Furthermore, each train has a five-digit train number, for example, one two zero zero one, used for searching train schedules and tracking its real-time location.

unnormalised: Bus tickets often contain a ticket number, typically an 8-digit or 9-digit number (e.g., 987654321). This number is crucial for boarding the bus and claiming any refunds or addressing grievances. Some private bus operators also use a booking ID that might resemble the airline's booking reference (e.g., XYZ98A). Always keep a copy of your bus ticket handy, as it's the primary proof of your booking.

unnormalised: Understanding these travel identifiers is essential for a smooth travel experience in India. Knowing the difference between a PNR, booking reference, transaction ID, and ticket number can save you time and prevent confusion when dealing with airlines, railways, or bus operators. Always verify that the identifiers on your ticket match the information in your booking confirmation to avoid any potential problems during your travels. Remember to keep these identifiers safe and readily accessible throughout your journey.
